segment.source: Domain controller Allow server operators to schedule tasks (Windows 10)
segment.target: Domain controller Allow server operators to schedule tasks (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Domain controller Allow server operators to schedule tasks security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Domain controller Allow server operators to schedule tasks security policy setting.

segment.source: Domain controller: Allow server operators to schedule tasks
segment.target: Domain controller: Allow server operators to schedule tasks

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Domain controller: Allow server operators to schedule tasks security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Domain controller: Allow server operators to schedule tasks security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines whether server operators can use theat command to submit jobs.
segment.target: This policy setting determines whether server operators can use theat command to submit jobs.

segment.source: If you enable this policy setting, jobs that are created by server operators by means of the at command run in the context of the account that runs the Task Scheduler service.
segment.target: If you enable this policy setting, jobs that are created by server operators by means of the at command run in the context of the account that runs the Task Scheduler service.

segment.source: By default, that is the Local System account.
segment.target: By default, that is the Local System account.

segment.source: Note: This security option setting affects only the scheduler tool for the at command.
segment.target: Note: This security option setting affects only the scheduler tool for the at command.

segment.source: It does not affect the Task Scheduler tool.
segment.target: It does not affect the Task Scheduler tool.

segment.source: Enabling this policy setting means jobs that are created by server operators through the at command will be executed in the context of the account that is running that service—by default, that is the Local System account.
segment.target: Enabling this policy setting means jobs that are created by server operators through the at command will be executed in the context of the account that is running that service—by default, that is the Local System account.

segment.source: This means that server operators can perform tasks that the Local System account is able to do, but server operators would normally not be able to do, such as add their account to the local Administrators group.
segment.target: This means that server operators can perform tasks that the Local System account is able to do, but server operators would normally not be able to do, such as add their account to the local Administrators group.

segment.source: The impact of enabling this policy setting should be small for most organizations.
segment.target: The impact of enabling this policy setting should be small for most organizations.

segment.source: Users, including those in the Server Operators group, will still be able to create jobs by using the Task Scheduler Wizard, but those jobs will run in the context of the account that the user authenticates with when setting up the job.
segment.target: Users, including those in the Server Operators group, will still be able to create jobs by using the Task Scheduler Wizard, but those jobs will run in the context of the account that the user authenticates with when setting up the job.

segment.source: Best practices for this policy are dependent on your security and operational requirements for task scheduling.
segment.target: Best practices for this policy are dependent on your security and operational requirements for task scheduling.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: The at command schedules commands and programs to run on a computer at a specified time and date.
segment.target: The at command schedules commands and programs to run on a computer at a specified time and date.

segment.source: The Schedule service must be running to use the at command.
segment.target: The Schedule service must be running to use the at command.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Tasks that run under the context of the Local System account can affect resources that are at a higher privilege level than the user account that scheduled the task.
segment.target: Tasks that run under the context of the Local System account can affect resources that are at a higher privilege level than the user account that scheduled the task.

segment.source: Disable the Domain controller: Allow server operators to schedule tasks setting.
segment.target: Disable the Domain controller: Allow server operators to schedule tasks setting.

segment.source: The impact should be small for most organizations.
segment.target: The impact should be small for most organizations.

segment.source: Users (including those in the Server Operators group) can still create jobs by means of the Task Scheduler snap-in.
segment.target: Users (including those in the Server Operators group) can still create jobs by means of the Task Scheduler snap-in.

segment.source: However, those jobs run in the context of the account that the user authenticates with when setting up the job.
segment.target: However, those jobs run in the context of the account that the user authenticates with when setting up the job.
